BMB161.name: Cell and Molecular Biology
BMB161.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB161.description: Macromolecular synthesis. Energy metabolism. Molecular aspects of development. Molecular genetics.
BMB161.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or concurrently) or (CEM 151 or concurrently) or (LB 171 or concurrently) or (CEM 181H or concurrently)

BMB171.name: Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory
BMB171.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB171.description: Principles and applications of common techniques used in cell and molecular biology.

BMB181H.name: Honors Cell and Molecular Biology
BMB181H.description: Physicochemical and molecular organization of cells as the unifying framework for genetics, evolution, and the social relevance of biology.
BMB181H.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or concurrently) or (CEM 151 or concurrently) or (CEM 181H or concurrently) or (LB 171 or concurrently)

BMB191H.name: Honors Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory
BMB191H.description: Basic techniques of cellular and molecular biology including experimental design and hypothesis formulation; biochemistry, molecular biology and genetics.

BMB200.name: Introduction to Biochemistry
BMB200.description: Introductions to the major classes of biomolecules and the metabolism of these molecules.

BMB400.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
BMB400.description: Managing and analyzing biological data with bioinformatic tools, basic programming, and statistics.
BMB400.prerequisite: (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421) and (PLB 203 or MMG 201 or BMB 200 or BS 161)

BMB401.name: Comprehensive Biochemistry
BMB401.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB401.description: Structure and function of major biomolecules, organization and regulation of metabolic pathways. Special emphasis on eukaryotic systems and the biochemical basis of human disease.
BMB401.restrictions: Not open to students in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology/Biotechnology Major or in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology major.

BMB410.name: Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
BMB410.description: Computational approaches in modern biology with a focus on applications in genomics, systems biology, evolution, and structural biology.
BMB410.prerequisite: {(CMSE 201 and LB 144 and LB 145) or (CMSE 201 and BS 161 and BS 162) or (CMSE 201 and BS 181H and BS 182H)} and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421 or STT 351 or ECE 280)

BMB411.name: Computational Medicine
BMB411.description: Computational approaches in biology with a focus on medicine.
BMB411.prerequisite: (CMSE 201 and LB 144 and LB 145) or (CMSE 201 and BS 161 and BS 162) or (CMSE 201 and BS 181H and BS 182H)

BMB461.name: Advanced Biochemistry I
BMB461.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
BMB461.description: Structure, function, and biophysical properties of biomolecules in a wide variety of organisms. Emphasis on proteins and carbohydrates including enzyme catalysis and kinetics, the central metabolic pathways, and photosynthesis.
BMB461.prerequisite: (CEM 251 or CEM 351) and (CEM 252 or CEM 352) and (MTH 124 or MTH 132 or MTH 152H or LB 118) and (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and ((BS 162 or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently))

BMB462.name: Advanced Biochemistry II
BMB462.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
BMB462.description: Continuation of BMB 461. Structure, function, and biophysical properties of lipids and nucleic acids including membranes, lipid metabolism, signaling and metabolic regulation, DNA replication and repair, transcription, translation, and regulation of gene expression.
BMB462.prerequisite: (BMB 461 or BMB 401) and (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and ((BS 162 or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently)) and (CEM 252 or CEM 352)

BMB469.name: Special Topics in Biochemistry
BMB469.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
BMB469.description: Special topics in biochemistry and molecular biology including biological computing, bioinformatics, biotechnology, genomics or other current topics.
BMB469.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology/Biotechnology Major or in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology major or in the Lyman Briggs Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs-Biochemistry/Biotechnology Coordinate Major or approval of department.

BMB470.name: Advanced Molecular Biology Laboratory
BMB470.description: Methods of molecular biology and the underlying principles on which these methods are based.
BMB470.restrictions: Open to students in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology/Biotechnology Major or in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology major or in the Lyman Briggs Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs-Biochemistry/Biotechnology Coordinate Major or approval of department.

BMB471.name: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory
BMB471.description: Biochemical methods and principles used in the study of enzymes (proteins), carbohydrates, lipids, and cell organelles.
BMB471.restrictions: Open to students in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology/Biotechnology Major or in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology major or in the Lyman Briggs Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs-Biochemistry/Biotechnology Coordinate Major or approval of department.

BMB490.name: Biochemistry Research
BMB490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB490.restrictions: Approval of department. A student may earn a maximum of 12 credits for BMB 490 and BMB 499.

BMB495.name: Undergraduate Seminar (W)
BMB495.description: Extension and synthesis of concepts of biochemistry. Relationships to societal issues.
BMB495.prerequisite: (BMB 462 or concurrently) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
BMB495.restrictions: Open to students in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology/Biotechnology Major or in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology major.

BMB499.name: Senior Thesis (W)
BMB499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB499.description: Laboratory research culminating in a thesis.
BMB499.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
BMB499.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of department. A student may earn a maximum of 12 credits for BMB 490 and BMB 499.

BMB514.name: Medical Biochemistry
BMB514.description: Basic biochemical principles and terminology; metabolism and function of biomolecules of importance in medical biology and human pathophysiology.
BMB514.restrictions: Open only to students in the College of Human Medicine and the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB515.name: Medical Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
BMB515.description: Basic biochemical principles and terminology. Overview of metabolism of biomolecules of importance to medical biology and human pathophysiology.
BMB515.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB516.name: Metabolic Biochemistry: Nutrients and Products
BMB516.description: Basic biochemical principles and terminology. Overview of metabolism of biomolecules of importance to medical biology and human pathophysiology.
BMB516.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB526.name: Molecular Biology and Medical Genetics
BMB526.description: Basic principles of human medical genetics; storage and expression of genetic information; transmission of genetic information to progeny.
BMB526.restrictions: Open only to students in the College of Human Medicine or the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB527.name: Medical Genetics
BMB527.description: Basic principles of human medical genetics. Storage and expression of genetic information. Transmission of genetic information to progeny.
BMB527.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB528.name: Molecular Biology and Medical Genetics
BMB528.description: Basic principles of molecular biology and human medical genetics. Storage and expression of genetic information. Transmission of genetic information to progeny.
BMB528.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB534.name: Cell Biology and Physiology I
BMB534.description: Modern concepts of cell biology as a basis for understanding the physiology of human tissues and organ systems in health and disease.
BMB534.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB535.name: Cell Biology and Physiology II
BMB535.description: Modern concepts of cell biology as a basis for understanding the physiology of human tissues and organ systems in health and disease. Continuation of PSL 534.
BMB535.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the College of Human Medicine or the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB539.name: Principles of Cell Biology and Pathophysiology
BMB539.description: Modern concepts of human cell biology as a basis for understanding integration of structure (histology) and function (physiology) in health and disease (pathology). Introduction to adaptive growth response, cell injury, inflammation, hemodynamic disorders, and tissue repair.
BMB539.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

BMB801.name: Molecular Biology
BMB801.description: Organization of genes. Regulation of gene expression, replication, and recombination.

BMB802.name: Metabolic Regulation and Signal Transduction
BMB802.description: Molecular basis for metabolic regulation. Molecular signalling mechanisms and mechanisms for allosteric and covalent protein modifications.

BMB803.name: Protein Structure and Function
BMB803.description: Protein structure and relationship of function to structure. Applications of kinetic methods to elucidation of enzyme mechanisms and regulation. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
BMB803.restrictions: Not open to students in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BMB805.name: Protein Structure, Design, and Mechanism
BMB805.description: Protein architecture, dynamics, folding, stability, and evolution. Conformational changes, ligand binding, and kinetics. Elucidation of enzyme mechanisms.

BMB810.name: Theories and Practices in Bioinformatics
BMB810.description: Theories and algorithms behind bioinformatics tools. Basic tool development by writing scripts in the Python programming language for data analysis.

BMB816.name: Integrative Toxicology: Mechanisms, Pathology and Regulation
BMB816.description: Biochemical, molecular, and physiological mechanisms of toxicology. Functional and pathological responses of major organ systems to chemical insult. Mechanisms of mutagenesis, carcinogenesis, and reproductive toxicology. Concepts in risk and safety assessment.

BMB825.name: Cell Structure and Function
BMB825.description: Molecular basis of structure and function. Cell properties

BMB829.name: Methods of Macromolecular Analysis and Synthesis
BMB829.description: Techniques of isolation and characterization of macromolecules. Computer use in structure-function analysis of macromolecules.

BMB855.name: Special Problems
BMB855.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB855.description: Laboratory or library research on special problems in biochemistry.

BMB856.name: Plant Molecular and Omic Biology
BMB856.description: Advanced genetics and molecular biology of higher plants.

BMB864.name: Plant Specialized Metabolism
BMB864.description: Specialized metabolism unique to photosynthetic organisms including aspects of nitrogen and sulfate assimilation and essential amino acid synthesis relevant to specialized metabolism, vitamin synthesis, mono-, di-, tri- and tetra-terpenoid synthesis, synthesis of phenylpropanoids and other aromatic compounds and synthesis of various alkaloids.
BMB864.prerequisite: BMB 461 or BMB 462 or (PLB 866 or concurrently)

BMB866.name: Molecular Plant Physiology
BMB866.description: Molecular basis of the physiology of plants including photosynthesis, respiration, primary metabolism, water relations, and nutrition. Quantitative and systems approaches are emphasized.

BMB899.name: Master's Thesis Research
BMB899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB899.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BMB960.name: Selected Topics in Biochemistry I
BMB960.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
BMB960.description: Selected topics in biochemistry with substantial student presentations.
BMB960.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology or approval of department.

BMB961.name: Selected Topics in Biochemistry II
BMB961.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
BMB961.description: Selected topics in biochemistry with faculty lectures, laboratory, or other instruction.
BMB961.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology or approval of department.

BMB978.name: Seminar in Biochemistry
BMB978.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
BMB978.description: Seminars on biochemistry research mainly with visiting scientists.
BMB978.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

BMB999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
BMB999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
BMB999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
